tweets.text:
A mile of the River Lugg has been bulldozed to destruction.
Bankside trees grubbed out & burnt.
Riverbed scraped out.
Meanders reprofiled.
Disaster for downstream wildlife.
This was an SSSI.
No consent was sought. 
@EnvAgency must surely prosecute this.
RT
https://t.co/cSBhrR2nDW

We are pleased to announce that our River Eye Catchment project in #leicestershire has been awarded a grant from the #GreenRecoveryChallengeFund We are excited to get started with this great project and to transform the Eye catchment! #TogetherForOurPlanet https://t.co/xH0wHiS1j9

First the River Cam, current overall environmental health 'Poor' Reasons for not reaching 'Good' status attached. (1/3) https://t.co/uTMSWl0Cxq

@greenarteries @TerryMac999 @markrwilliamson @dottymcl @BBCCambs @CambsCC @wre @GreaterCambs @EnvAgency Secondly the River Granta, current overall environmental health "Moderate" Reasons for not reaching 'Good' status attached. (2/3)

entity.name: Countryfile
entity.description: Stories are shared of the people, places and issues at the heart of the British countryside. Popular features include the programme's photography contest, which culminates in a yearly calendar sold to benefit charity, the Video Diary, produced by viewers and focused on life in rural areas, and the weather forecasts.

tweets.text: The upper-left of the old map shows lots of boggy ground. If the @EnvAgency could direct land managers to this sort of evidence and insist that restoration of water retentive land is the solution to flooding - which it is - the Lugg situation may be avoided in the future https://t.co/43jApqiIu7

For those wondering what's happened to the River Lugg above Leominster, this aerial photo (2020) & map (1953) are instructive. The farmer claims that he had to clear the river to reduce flooding. But look how the landscape has changed. Intensive agriculture depends on drainage. https://t.co/YEIezrgBnq

Brilliant news and something we @EnvAgencyMids will be supporting. Exciting times ahead where improvements to #water and surrounding #environment will benefit both people and wildlife whilst also creating some fantastic training and job opportunities. Great work @thetamevalley üëç https://t.co/t9TNhaadGg

tweets.text:
The #Lincolnshire beach management team have been reprofiling a section of the beach at Winthorpe near Skegness.
 
Reprofiling is where you move sand and build it up so it is the height and width it needs to be to protect what's behind it. This is expected routine work. #Beach https://t.co/rLPYAQ2OWh

So pleased to join @EmmaHowardBoyd @SaleemulHuq to discuss the huge challenges that water brings and how we can #adapt and become #resilient across our planet #TogetherForOurPlanet @COP26 https://t.co/rFUFoDWO7l
